title: Henri Bergson - Philosophical Works (13 books)
description:
HENRI-LOUIS BERGSON (1859-1941) was an influential French philosopher who convinced many thinkers that the processes of immediate experience and intuition are more significant than abstract rationalism and science for understanding reality.  He was awarded the 1927 Nobel Prize in Literature "in recognition of his rich and vitalizing ideas and the brilliant skill with which they have been presented."

Bergson developed his philosophy in a number of books that have become famous not only for their fresh interpretation of life but also for a powerful employment of metaphor, image, and analogy.  In TIME AND FREE WILL (1889), his doctoral thesis, Bergson offered an interpretation of consciousness as existing on two levels, the first to be reached by deep introspection, the second an external projection of the first.  The deeper self is the seat of creative becoming and of free will.  The method of intuitive introspection, first employed in this work, is developed further in AN INTRODUCTION TO METAPHYSICS (1903).

In MATTER AND MEMORY (1896), Bergson again took up the study of consciousness, turning his attention to the relation of mind to body, arguing that this distinction is one of degree, not of kind.  The limiting concept of matter is interpreted as a momentary mind, completely deprived of a memory that helps make possible freedom of choice.  CREATIVE EVOLUTION (1907) provided an alternate explanation for Darwin's mechanism of evolution and developed the concept of time introduced in Bergson's other works and applied it to the study of living things, while THE TWO SOURCES OF MORALITY AND RELIGION (1932) extended these theories to the realms of morality, religion and art.

Many of his essays, lectures and reviews are collected in MIND-ENERGY (1919) and his final book, THE CREATIVE MIND (1946), a masterly autobiography of his philosophical method.
